Identifying Characteristics: Varying shades of brown and red—most have a black marking over the eyes that looks like a robber’s mask
Individual frogs are capable of varying their color
Underparts are pale with a yellow or green cast
Biology: They are one of the first amphibians to emerge for breeding right when the snow melts—by breeding in early spring wood frogs increase their offspring's chances of metamorphosing before pools dry
Males breeding choruses are duck-like quacking sounds
Females deposit eggs attached to submerged substrate, typically vegetation or downed branches—most deposit eggs adjacent to other egg masses, creating large aggregations of masses
The egg masses (of a few hundred eggs each) are deposited in communal clusters
Gelatin covering, communal clusters, and exposure to the sun all help the eggs to be warmer than the surrounding water and develop faster
By mid to late April small black tadpoles are abundant in vernal pools feeding on the leaves and algae of the pool and they grow quickly and become a green-brown color
By June the tadpoles will have developed legs and are absorbing their tail in preparation for leaving the pool
Habitat: Adults spend summer months in moist woodlands, forested swamps, ravines, or bogs
During the fall they leave summer habitats and migrate to neighboring uplands to overwinter
Take shelter in leaf litter during winter months
Diet: Adults feed on insects, arachnids, slugs, worms, and snails
Range: From northern Georgia and northeastern Canada in the east to Alaska and southern British Columbia in the west
Most widely distributed frog in Alaska
